key_insight: HiStream cuts the huge inference cost of high-resolution video diffusion by eliminating redundant computation: denoise at low resolution, stream the video in chunks, and reuse cached features to cheaply refine to high resolution.
problem_solved: High-resolution video generation with diffusion models is computationally and memory intensive (quadratic complexity), making practical inference infeasible for long or high-res videos due to repeated, redundant computations across spatial resolution, temporal frames, and denoising steps.
method: Spatial compression — perform denoising at low resolution first, then refine to high resolution using cached multi-scale features to avoid re-computing heavy high-res convolutions.
Temporal compression — generate video chunk-by-chunk (streaming) with overlapped context and feature reuse to avoid repeatedly processing the entire temporal sequence.
Cross-step feature reuse — cache and reuse intermediate denoising features across steps and frames so redundant per-step computations are skipped.
impact: HiStream significantly lowers compute, memory, and latency for high-res video diffusion, enabling practical generation and faster iteration on commodity hardware — useful for video production, editing, and real-time or low-cost deployment.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: low-res denoiser → feature cache → high-res refiner (show arrows and reduced compute at each stage).
Streaming timeline: video split into overlapping chunks with arrows showing feature transfer/reuse between adjacent chunks.
Bar chart or table: compute/latency and memory comparison (HiStream vs standard diffusion) highlighting percent reduction.
Feature-cache heatmap or memory map: illustrate which features are reused across spatial/temporal axes and how much computation is avoided.
paper_title: HiStream: Efficient High-Resolution Video Generation via Redundancy-Eliminated Streaming
paper_authors: Haonan Qiu, Shikun Liu, Zijian Zhou, Zhaochong An, Weiming Ren
